greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = largest base-2 palindrome m <= 2n+1 such that every base-2 digit of m is <= the corresponding digit of 2n+1; m is written in base 10.
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..8191
maple: ispal := proc(n) # test for base-b palindrome
if L[i] <> L[Ln + 1 - i] then return false end if
# find max pal <= n and in base-b shadow of n, write in base 10
if n mod b = 0 then return(0); fi;
for m from n by -1 to 0 do
for i from 1 to L2 do
if t2[i] > t1[i] then sw1:=-1; break; fi;
# find max pal <= n and in base-b shadow of n, write in base b
if n mod b = 0 then return(0); fi;
for m from n by -1 to 0 do
for i from 1 to L2 do
if t2[i] > t1[i] then sw1:=-1; break; fi;
if sw1=1 then mb:=add(t2[i]*10^(i-1), i=1..L2); return(mb); fi;
mathematica: A265509 = FromDigits[Min /@ Transpose[{#, Reverse@#}], 2] &@IntegerDigits[2 # + 1, 2] & (* _JungHwan Min_, Aug 22 2016 *)
program: f (bs:_:bss) pss = y : f bss pss' where
y = foldr (\d v -> 2 * v + d) 0 ys
(ys:_) = dropWhile (\ps -> not $ and $ zipWith (<=) ps bs) pss'
pss' = if bs /= reverse bs then pss else bs : pss
xref: Sequences related to palindromic floor and ceiling: A175298, A206913, A206914, A261423, A262038, and the large block of consecutive sequences beginning at A265509.
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Dec 09 2015
